ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Readings, documentaries, breakout rooms, discussion boards.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to analyze and investigate social movements with the tools that political scientists use.

I learned about the methodological and theoretical underpinnings of the study of political protests, considered the role of social media in facilitating or inhibiting modern protests, and studied a number of case studies of historical and modern-day protests.
I learned a lot about political philosphy

Political Protests was an amazing course! This course focuses on the theory of protest and examines protest movements through an analytical lens. 
The discussions were incredibly engaging, the readings wonderful, and Prof. Hierro is incredible!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths of this course - varied and interesting mix of assignments and readings, Professor was always enthusiastic about the course materials, guest speakers were amazing, discussion was always lively.

It is a great course that is not just interesting but applicable to anyone interested in social movements. It integrates a broad range of examples of social movements. Another strength is that it integrates different types of assignments so they do not feel monotonous throughout the semester.

Strengths: The class is really tailored to students' learning, from the sheer amount of guest speakers Professor Hierro brought in, to the great environment our class was able to foster during the Zoom session. Out of all my classes this semester, it came the closest to replicating the feeling of being in a physical seminar. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes the sheer bulk of assignments got to be overwhelming. None of them were too difficult individually, but it could be a lot to juggle two larger papers, three reading responses,  two film responses, and three quizzes.

I can't decide whether the discussions or the readings were my favorite part of this class - both were interesting, engaging, and made me excited to learn every week. Readings were not overwhelming and clearly laid out both political theory and its practical implications, and the discussions each week were fun and captivating. I don't think the course had any weaknesses.

Strengths: engaging, interesting

Weaknesses: readings sometimes too dense

This course has many strengths and almost no weaknesses. The readings were an appropriate quantity and always engaging. There are many short papers, of which I was initially skeptical, but they are a great opportunity to explore new topics. Prof. Hierro is a very fair grader and facilitates class discussions in an incredibly-engaging manner. We had many guest speakers throughout the semester which made the course even more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I loved how the professor began sending out "summary google docs" for each session and we could comment on the google doc to facilitate further discussion outside of class. 
The only things I can think of for improvement is maybe put in more breakout rooms and come up with a more orderly way of figuring out who is talking in what order during discussion (perhaps using the raised hand function? not sure).

Breakout rooms during the seminar really helped facilitated closer relationships with my fellow peers, and allowed for collaboration. The online setting also made it easier for us to have multiple guest speakers, which I really appreciated.

The virtual seminar was shockingly effective and successful. I took many seminars this semester, and by the end I was almost always ready to shut off the computer, but in this course I found myself hoping for more time for discussion. I didn't experience "Zoom fatigue," even when we forgot to take breaks (because the conversation was so interesting), and almost every student seemed excited to participate.
The documentaries were fascinating and informative

Prof. Hierro utilized the breakout rooms feature on Zoom, giving students the opportunity not only to discuss topics from the course but also to get to know each other on a more personal level. Prof. Hierro gave us a five minute break in the middle of the seminar, which helped with Zoom fatigue. Prof. Hierro was incredibly attentive to students' needs and feedback regarding the pandemic and utilized many tools from the Poorvu Center to make the course engaging over the Zoom format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely. The material is super relevant and diverse, the professor is great, the assignments really allow you to explore your own thoughts... I could go on. I also think it's very important for young people to understand the history of protest and how we got to where we are today.
Yes! Professor Hierro is an amazing teacher.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The topic of protests is perpetually relevant (perhaps now more than ever) and Professor Hierro is a phenomenal professor that creates a wonderful seminar environment for her students.

Absolutely. This was one of the best classes I've ever taken at Yale - even as a Zoom seminar. If you have the chance to take it, whether virtual or in person, please do. Professor Hierro is wonderful and helps you to understand complex theory while keeping discussion accessible and engaging, and the course covers so many relevant and important topics.
Definitely!
Absolutely! A lovely class with a lovely professor!
Yes I absolutely would.

Yes! This course is a wonderful combination of theory and case studies! The workload is manageable and Prof. Hierro is incredible! She constantly gives feedback and is very attentive to her students' needs, especially during the pandemic. The  material of the course is fascinating and I feel as though I have learned an immense amount regarding the theory of protest, as well as various examples of protest movements throughout history. I  looked forward to going to class each week! Take this course!
